entries.content: Prospect uses 'planning to look into BIOS in the next year just not now' as a reason not to engage immediately.
entries.notes: Example of a common 'think about it' or 'later' stall.

entries.content: Handle the 'next year' stall by asking 'May I ask why your team is looking into vials?' to uncover the specific trigger or need.
entries.notes: Attempting to understand the underlying motivation for the future plan.

entries.content: Reflection: 'Should have pushed for the meeting' when a prospect uses a stall like 'next year' or 'send me an email'.
Core principle: 'Always get the meeting' when faced with stalls; don't easily accept 'send me an email' or 'next year'.
entries.notes: Strong emphasis on pushing for a defined next step.

entries.content: Prospect suggests 'What you can do is just send me an email' as a way to end the call.
entries.notes: Common stall/brush-off often following a soft 'think about it' or 'later'.

entries.content: Attempt a conditional close when asking for a referral: 'Would it be easier if I sent you just a very basic email... and perhaps could forward it along?'
entries.notes: Framing sending information as a way to make it easier for the prospect to take the suggested next step (forwarding).

entries.content: Offer mobile number for direct contact after a referral is agreed upon, facilitating easier follow-up than just an email.
entries.notes: Providing multiple contact options to increase the chance of the referral leading to a conversation.

focus_area: Handling "Think About It": "What specifically?", Conditional closing
